title: Are yakuza still powerful today in Japan? - Quora
tags: Yakuza (organized crime syndicates originating in Japan)

response.answer_text: They are powerful but nothing like before. They are actually dying and trying to find a way to survive. It's been years now that the yakuza's strength, power, influence are shrinking. To the point that now they have to think on how to stay alive and change the nature of their operations. The number of yakuza decreased significantly over the past 20 years. The Japanese government played its part and initiated a Tolerance 0 Program which seems to give results. They strike hard, following the money, turning businesses against the yakuza and playing their role by providing real protection to those who accept to refuse to make any deal with the yakuza, they do more real police work to catch the leaders etc.... Does that mean that the yakuza are gone or lost complete influence? Of course not, but they are seriously wounded. It would probably take 1 or 2 generations while keeping the same strategy to get rid of them, unless the yakuza manage to reinvent themselves which is what they are trying to do now. They are talking of leaving the shady businesses to turn into white collar type of activities, finance etc.... The yakuza ranks are bleeding. It's very simple, just need to compare the different eras. The golden age 10 years ago, 5 years ago (when the government stroke even harder with the anti gang law), and now. What's going on is that the Yamaguchi gumi counted 35 000 members 5 years ago and now only 25 000. -30% in only 5 years!! The question is what happened? The numbers are even more shocking when we look at all yakuza organizations. They have a hard time recruiting when it should be quite the opposite in this crisis and nationalism revival era. What's going on? Many yakuza have to go underground to survive or quit because they have a hard time to keep up in this business. New generations of politics are not so keen to be linked and rely on the yakuza in regards of the latest events and what is at stake. The latest events not being the code of silence and almost total impunity like it used to be, but total exposure for everybody even people considered untouchable. The media don't keep silent about the yakuza anymore. What's going on now is that there is a huge operation to make people turn their back and cut all ties with the yakuza. Big operations to clean the police ranks, justice etc...to make the whole thing happen. There is no breaking news here, It's all over the press. Jake Adelstein often writes about it. The yakuza are not even safe abroad anymore. The US West coast is their second HQ. It's been decades the yakuza have been in the US messing with the stock markets. Now the US is striking hard on the money which is a direct order from Tokyo in this big strategy for which one of the big lines is to touch the money. " In 2007, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported that the head of a Kodo-kai faction took over Yubitoma, the equivalent of Japan’s “Find High School Alumni, Yearbooks, & Reunions,” gaining access to the personal data of 3.5 million people." This is totally what we call white collar career change. There is nothing illegal and it's a smart move. This is for example what many IT businesses do all the time.

Check out the book "Yakuza". I read it back in the 1980's and the authors both writers for the NYTimes issued an updated version lately. The Yakuza are still a powerhouse in white slavery throughout the pacific rim, and run prostitution and pornography in Japan. Their tentacles go back to the US occupation of Japan and the US military governorship under MacArthur using them to counter the growth of communism in destitute post war Japan. Many ultra nationalists aka Japanese war criminals made a fortune in Manchuria during the war and avoided criminal punishment due to their usefulness to the US. However this just served as a launching platform for the Yakuza into Japanese national politics, where they remain firmly entrenched today. As recently as 1970's the sitting Prime Minister had to step down due to a vote buying scandal on the part of the Yakuza and the dominant political party. That same party the Liberal Democrat Party had stayed in office for some forty years and only in 2010 suffered its first defeat by the Democrat Party of Japan. The LDP is the ultra conservative party despite its name. They regained power in 2014.

You would probably not believe this, but the mafia in Japan (the Yakuza) is literally present in everyday live, and people see them in their daily lives. Their main headquarters are in Fukuoka, where you can see them everywhere. The police in Japan are actually working for the Yakuza, you’re probably not going to believe this, but it’s true, i have personally seen this myself, and i have heard the same story from multiple people before, where a yakuza would be doing something illegal right next to a cop, and he would just stand and not do anything. Police in Japan is not really a police, they are just there for the facade, the Yakuza are the real police, and a lot of people say they are keeping the crime low, which is true. Yakuza is very tightly related to the government, and during the Fukushima disaster, they are also very involved in taking homeless people and sending them to work around Fukushima. They are also involved in the sex industry, prostitution industry and entertainment industry. If you don’t bother them, they won’t bother you. Well they are  generally considered to be the most powerful mafia Group in the World today. Particularly, the pre-WW2 Yamaguchi-gumi syndicate, which reportedly boasts nearly 35.000 members, and in 2014 it was estimated to bring in nearly 80 billion dollars a year. Like other mafias, they deal in gambling, prostitution, extortion, and above all, drugs. 35% of their income is said to come from drug trafficking in Japan.
